title: Have you ever tried to change your handwriting? Why or why not? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have not tried to change my handwriting before, and I do not think I ever will. But of course, my handwriting has changed, just without me consciously putting effort into it. Here’s my handwriting at the beginning of middle school:  I don’t know. It is readable, but of course, it doesn’t look that good. Then here’s me at the beginning of high school:  I mean, can you even read that?? I’d be surprised if you can, because it’s basically unreadable! I have no idea how my handwriting got to this. But honestly, in the end, I don’t really care.  So, why don’t I care about my handwriting? Everybody keeps saying it’d look better, or it’d be more readable, but why waste time improving my handwriting when I can just write even better? Just look at this piece of art:  Don’t you see how perfect that writing is? Seriously, at least it’s readable, right? Plus, nowadays almost everything is shared or submitted online or printed. What’s the point of writing? And here’s something I made:  So yeah. That’s why I won’t spend my time improving my handwriting.  Okay, I feel like I gotta put some more. One time, I did try to change my handwriting. That was in Spanish class:  You can see in problem A, I was going with my normal handwriting. Then, suddenly I was like, “Hey, you know what, I got time today. Why don’t we have some fun?” And I clenched my pencil tight, slammed my cheek to the table, and wrote as slowly and as straight as I could. But in the end, it remained my personal inside joke and I never tried it again. It took way too long.  Soo… I couldn’t really find any work from very-young-me, which I think wrote much neater. However, I got some stuff of my Chinese handwriting! Yay! Here’s me in 3rd grade:  It actually looks very nice to me. In 2nd grade, I was much better, and my classmates and even my teacher would applaud me. But unfortunately, I can’t find any from that time. Here’s me in 9th grade:  If you read Chinese, it’ll be easier to see. But if you don’t I don’t know if you can tell which one’s better or worse. But for certain it’s worse.  But of course, I still got my signature.

All the time. My handwriting is appalling. No, seriously. I know many people say that about their own, but take a look at my handwriting.  Of course, that’s writing a single sentence, and my writing seems to be neater when writing a sentence, as opposed to a whole paragraph. Also I wrote it on my computer, dunno if that that impacts on any thing. Sometimes, I can actually try to write neatly.  But it takes quite a while to write *really* neat. Let’s insert some lines to see if that helps at all. First, my usual messy writing on lines…  And my careful, neat writing on lines.  I can write really small (again lines so you can see how small it is).  When I write small, I generally write much neater as opposed to writing very largely.  I’d like to write in cursive, but when I do it very quickly, it just doesn’t look very good.  But if I really take my time with it…  Okay I’ll admit - my writing isn’t THAT BAD in small doses, but when I can, I’ll show you what my study notes look like. Writing on the computer generally makes my writing neater, but it depends if my stylus is fucked up or not (if it is, my handwriting would be even more atrocious). I would love to be able to just change my handwriting, as even I struggle to read my own scrawl sometimes. Hello, my name is Rainie. ;)

Maybe the answer is different depending on whether you are talking about printing or cursive? I remember two situations where I consciously made changes. The first was during college. I was taking a lot of notes as the professors were lecturing. In my effort to keep up with what I needed to write down I developed some shorthand words for things I wrote a lot like bc for because and w/o for without. I had others but those most readily spring to mind. This most likely doesn’t apply anymore as I believe laptops are the new way? The other one came about with cursive when I was in my 30’s. I have a “glia” at the end of my last name that I didn’t like the way it looked in my signature and was also a stumbler when I just wrote cursive g’s in general. I got a Christmas card from an aunt and loved her fluidity with g’s and j’s so I sat down and practiced both and that changed my cursive and printing forever. Not only were they faster but they also made my handwriting more grownup. Thank you auntie!

I have for sure changed my handwriting. It looks a lot different now than what it did. I don’t think that there’s a sure fire reason that I did, maybe only because I saw how someone else wrote a letter and I liked it that way better than mine. It’s strange how I did it, too. I changed one letter or number at a time. If I didn’t like one little thing, I would change only that one little thing. It’s strange, and I still do it sometimes if I notice something I want to change. I think I also found it interesting that using the sheer willpower of my brain EVERY single time I wrote that specific thing, I could change it for good. Anywho, that’s my short little story on that. Thanks for listening! :) love, Joy

Yes, many times… The start of grade 8, I had NORMAL cursive hand writing it looked like this kinda:  I only wrote in cursive for like all of grade 7 and September of grade 8, but then a teacher told me to “not write in cursive Becuase not every one can read it” yes, in 8th grade, students cannot read cursive, also, WHY ARE STUDENTS READING MY WORK?! Anyways, I changed and now it looks more like this:  I also write my capital e like a backwards 3, apparently my a’s looks so wired that my friends will watch me write just to see the way I write them (don’t ask) So I changed my hand writing all Becuase one teacher didn’t like cursive… UGH

Yes, I have. I had this scratchy scribble handwriting until the end of sixth grade. Then over the summer, being a nerd, I took math notes for the next year while practicing my handwriting. It started like this:  Then, I looked up good handwriting online and tried to copy my favorites. I spent a lot of time on this part.  Notice how it’s more round? Now, I have made my handwriting messier but smaller. These are my geometry notes: *yawn*  Also, for subjects other than math, I have more freedom to draw pictures and add more color.  Thanks for reading my handwriting evolution! sienna

I did this once back in grade four, because I *for some weird reason I can’t remember* thought the teacher wanted us to write exactly like her. Her handwriting looked like a cross between cursive and print — every letter she wrote was adorned with a fancy “curly q.” Thank God that didn’t last for long. It wasn’t until a few months later when I said to myself, “screw this,” and decided to do things my own way. Now my handwriting looks like this:  This photo was taken from one of my notebooks. I’m in the middle of writing a story.

everyday. i have weird dysphoria about my handwriting because when its neat i feel like it looks to feminine. heres how it usually is  heres me trying to be neat  my regular cursive  neat cursive  now the same thing but messy italian (i just need practice)  now my neat italian

Yes. I hold my pencil in a super strange way and all my teachers tried to get me to conform to the normal way. It didn’t work, and I went on having ugly, messy handwriting. Last year at the beginning of the year I decided to change it to look better. I practiced a lot and started looping the letters q,y,g,j, and curving my v’s and w’s. It has really payed off, and now, though still massive, my handwriting is extremely satisfying to look at once written.

I actually change my handwriting a lot, depending on the hand I write with, mood and lazyness. Here's how I wtite most of the time:  Here's me writing with my left hand:  Here's me on mondays:  On fridays:  And here's my handwriting when I write my native language:  Thanks for reading this boring post lol 💖💖💖💫🎐🎀
